</associatedParty> <pubDate>2010</pubDate> <abstract> <para>This project was started by Haines and Crossley in 1992 to compare leaf litter weights among the five gradient plots (though data from the first collections were not included in this dataset because the original dataset did not represent a complete quarter of collection).  Litter is collected from ten 0.92x0.92 m leaf collectors within each of the gradient plots. Litter is collected on a quarterly basis (monthly in the autumn).  The litter is then separated by category, dried, weighed, and processed in a Wiley mill for later nutrient analyses.  Since the project first started, the collection process has expanded to include non-leaf litter (e.g., lichens, bark, and seeds), fine twigs (0-2.5 cm diameter), and medium twigs (2.5-10 cm diameter).</para> </abstract> <keywordSet> <keyword keywordType="theme">Coweeta Hydrologic Laboratory</keyword> <keyword keywordType="theme">deciduous</keyword> <keyword keywordType="theme">leaf litter</keyword> <keyword keywordType="theme">mass</keyword> <keyword keywordType="theme">pine</keyword> <keyword keywordType="theme">Rhododendron maximum</keyword> <keyword </contact> <publisher><references>CWT-LTER</references></publisher> <methods> <methodStep> <description> <section> <title>Coarse Grinding</title> <para>"Coarse Grinding -- 1. Make sure the unit is clean before beginning. 2. Close door and turn grinder ON. 3. Feed samples into the hopper, using large wood plunger if necessary. 4. Use throat plate as necessary to prevent debris from flying out of top. 5. Empty collection cup as necessary (turn grinder off first). 6. Remove collection cup when grinding is finished, place large bowl under front of grinder, open grinder and sweep material out of grinder into bowl using paint brush. 7. Combine all materials and thoroughly mix. 8. Clean the grinder, paint brush, & mixing bowl by brushing/vacuuming. "</para> </section> </description> </methodStep> <methodStep> <description> <section> <title>Fine Grinding</title> <para>"Fine Grinding -- 1. Make sure the unit is clean. Check the air filter on back of unit and vacuum as needed. 2. Press START (12,000 rpm). 3. Add 5 large spoonfuls of well mixed coarse material into chute without causing the motor to bog down. Grinding is very rapid. Do not use black plastic funnel inserts. 4. Press STOP, allow a few seconds for the automatic cover to release. Open the grinder. 5. Remove the collection bowl and use a clean paint brush with small funnel to fill vials. 6. Fill 1 vial to 80% full. 7. Archiving \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIf the amount pf material is less than \ufffd\ufffd vial, do not prepare a second vial. If the amount is equal or greater than \ufffd\ufffd vial, prepare 2 vials of equal parts. 8. Vacuum blades, grinding wheel, cover plate, etc. If debris sticks to the lid or other parts, wipe the area with a dry paper towel and finish vacuuming."</para> </section> </description> </methodStep> <methodStep> <description> <section> <title>General Grinding</title> <para>"General Grinding -- Grind like tissues (all deciduous, rhodo, twig); With very small samples (hemlock, pine), do not coarse grind. Feed directly into fine grinder (will need to prepare pine needles by cutting into small pieces); Thoroughly clean the grinders and your work area when finished. "</para> </section> </description> </methodStep> <methodStep> <description> <section> <title>Weighing</title> <para>Weighing -- Litter should be thoroughly dried before weighing. This includes re-drying the litter overnight if the litter has already been dried, sorted, and stored. Litter to be weighed should come directly from the drying oven. Even litter left a few hours out of the oven will begin to absorb moisture from the air and gain mass. Litter can be weighed in the bag. However, 1) make sure to tare the bag weight, or 2) weigh at least 4-5 dried, empty bags of the same type and subtract the average weight of these bags from the weight of the bags of litter. Important - make sure bags are from the same manufacturer. Even bags that are the same size may weigh \ufffd\ufffd1g if they are from different manufacturers or even from different \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdruns\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd double check to make sure the tared bags and bags with leaf litter are the same. You may also empty the contents of the bag into a small lightweight container. Ideally, the container should not weigh much more than the litter. Make sure the container is tared before weighing. If you have just a small amount of litter, weigh the material directly on the scale. The readings become distorted if you try to weigh 2-3 hemlock needles in a bag or container that weighs 1000\ufffd\ufffd the weight of the needles. If litter is too small to register on the scale, make a note of it on the comments. Do not record 0.01 if the weight of the needle or leaf fragment is beyond the detection limit of the instrument (i.e., the instrument reads 0.00 even with leaf fragments/needles on the scale).</para> </section> </description> </methodStep> <methodStep> <description> <section> <title>General</title> <para> Litter is collected from 10 0.92 \ufffd\ufffd 0.92 m leaf collectors within each of the gradient plots. The litter traps are approximately 1 m high.  Litter is collected at the end of each quarter (monthly in the autumn): Quarter 1: April \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd June,  Quarter 2: July \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd September, Quarter 3: October \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd December, Quarter 4: January \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd March After the litter is collected, the samples are sorted into several categories: Deciduous leaves, Pine needles, Rhododendron leaves, Other (loose bark, seeds, nuts, loose lichens, etc.), Fine twigs (0-2.5 cm diameter), Medium twigs (2.5-10 cm diameter). The samples are then dried at 65\ufffd\ufffd C for 48 hours or until dry.  The samples are then weighed to the nearest 0.01 g.  After weighing, the samples are combined from each category/site and processed in a Wiley mill before being placed in scintillation vials for nutrient analysis (1 sample of each is preserved for archiving).</para> </section> </description> </methodStep> <sampling> <studyExtent> <coverage> <temporalCoverage> <rangeOfDates> <beginDate> <calendarDate>1994-10-01</calendarDate> </beginDate> <endDate> <calendarDate>2013-12-31</calendarDate> </endDate> </rangeOfDates> </temporalCoverage> </coverage> <coverage> <geographicCoverage> <geographicDescription>CWT Study Site WS18 -- Watershed 18, North Carolina, USA.  Grady Branch Watershed. Control watershed undisturbed since 1927. Records begin  3 July 1936. 120 degree V-notch weir.</geographicDescription> <boundingCoordinates> <westBoundingCoordinate>-83.436027</westBoundingCoordinate> <eastBoundingCoordinate>-83.431865</eastBoundingCoordinate> <northBoundingCoordinate>35.051388</northBoundingCoordinate> <southBoundingCoordinate>35.045522</southBoundingCoordinate> </boundingCoordinates> </geographicCoverage> <geographicCoverage> <geographicDescription>CWT Study Site WS27 -- Watershed 27, North Carolina, USA.  Hard Luck Creek Watershed. Control watershed with records beginning 2 Nov. 1946. The weir is a 120 degree V notch. Partially defoliated by fall cankerworm infestations from 1972 to 1979.</geographicDescription> <boundingCoordinates> <westBoundingCoordinate>-83.464543</westBoundingCoordinate> <eastBoundingCoordinate>-83.458009</eastBoundingCoordinate> <northBoundingCoordinate>35.038446</northBoundingCoordinate> <southBoundingCoordinate>35.029138</southBoundingCoordinate> </boundingCoordinates> </geographicCoverage> </coverage> </studyExtent> <samplingDescription> <section> <title>Terrestrial gradient leaf litter weights</title> <para>See site descriptions.</para> <para>This project is part of a larger examination of site productivity along an elevational gradient.  Leaf litter collections were started by Haines and Crossley in 1992 to compare leaf litter weights among the five gradient plots (though data from the first collections were not included in this dataset because the original dataset did not represent a complete quarter of collection).  Litter is collected from 10 0.92 \ufffd\ufffd 0.92 m leaf collectors within each of the gradient plots. Litter is collected on a quarterly basis (monthly in the autumn).  The litter is then separated by category, dried, weighed, and processed in a Wiley mill for later nutrient analyses.  Since the project first started, the collection process has expanded to include non-leaf litter (e.g., lichens, bark, and seeds), fine twigs (0-2.5 cm diameter), and medium twigs (2.5-10 cm diameter).</para> <para>Ten leaf litter traps at the Terrestrial Gradient permanent plots were collected at the end of each quarter.  The "leaf year" began on April 1st and ended the following year on March 31st.  So quarter one was April - June, quarter 2 was July - September, quarter 3 was October - December, and quarter 4 was the following year, January - March.  During the fall months (quarter 3), litter from traps was collected monthly.  There are currently x categories of litter: 1) Deciduous - includes all deciduous trees, as well as mountain laurel and hemlock needles; 2) Pine - includes white pine and yellow pine needles; 3) Rhododendron - includes leaves from Rhododendron maximum; 4) Other - includes bark, lichens, seeds, acorns, flower parts, and other material that is not a leaf or twig; 5) Twigs 2.5 - woody twigs <2.5 cm in diameter; 6) Twigs 2.5-10 - twigs between 2.5 & 10 cm in diameter.</para> </section> </samplingDescription> <spatialSamplingUnits> <referencedEntityId>1121.kml</referencedEntityId> </spatialSamplingUnits> </sampling> </methods> <project><title>Coweeta LTER Program V</title> <personnel> <individualName> <givenName>Ted</givenName> <givenName>L</givenName> <surName>Gragson</surName> </individualName> <role>principalInvestigator</role> </personnel> <personnel> <individualName> <givenName>James</givenName> <surName>Vose</surName> </individualName> <role>principalInvestigator</role> </personnel> <personnel> <individualName> <givenName>Brian</givenName> <surName>Kloeppel</surName> </individualName> <role>principalInvestigator</role> </personnel> <personnel> <individualName> <givenName>James</givenName> <givenName>Barrie</givenName> <surName>Collins</surName> </individualName> <role>informationManager</role> </personnel> <abstract> <para>The Coweeta LTER Research Program has evolved since 1980 from a site-based to a site- and region-based project examining the effects of disturbance and environmental gradients on biogeochemical cycling, and the underlying watershed ecosystem processes that regulate and respond to those cycles. The current interdisciplinary research integrates ecological and socioeconomic components across 54,000 km2 of the southern Appalachian Mountains, a biogeophysical and socioeconomic region in which evolutionary and historical processes converge (Whittaker 1956, Markusen 1987, Barnes 1991, Kretzschmar et al. 1993, Bailey 1996). Our research objective in 2002-2008 is to advance scientific understanding of the spatial, temporal, and decision-making components of land use and land-use change in the southern Appalachian Mountains over the last 200 years, and forecast patterns into the future 30 years. Our guiding hypothesis is that the frequency, intensity, and extent of land use represents human decision-making in response to socioeconomic and biogeophysical conditions with consequences that cascade through ecosystems.</para> </abstract> <funding> <para>This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under grant number OCE-9982133. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in the material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.</para> </funding> </project> <dataTable> <entityName>1121</entityName> <entityDescription>Litterfall Dry Mass, 1994-2013</entityDescription> <physical> <objectName>1121_1_0.TXT</objectName> <size </subStep> </methodStep> <qualityControl> <description> <para>Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). Qualifier flags are also assigned to values that are imputed or derived, revised, or otherwise differ from values in the original data submission. A column of coded qualifier flags is generated and included in the data table if flags are assigned to any value in a data column.</para> </description> </qualityControl> </methods> <additionalInfo> <para>Data Anomalies: Most anomalies are listed in the comments.  In 2008, there were high winds that blew most of the leaves out of traps located at plot 527 in quarter 3, so these data should be flagged.  There are other quarters where the mass of leaves from 527 is conspicuously low, which might be the product of the high winds at this site - the leaves are particularly susceptible to being blow out when we have winds out of the north in the fall and winter.  To try and keep leaves from blowing out of the traps, we tested four traps by placing skirts around the bottom of the traps using landscape cloth.  On February 23, 2011, we painted 20 leaves red and placed them in modified and unmodified traps at 527 and found that the modified traps with skirts kept 90-100% of their leaves after a month (checked on March 22, 2011), while the other traps lost anywhere from 25-100% of their marked leaves.  Based on this experiment, we placed skirts around all the traps at 527 on April 1st, 2011 (the beginning of Q1).  The following year on April 1st 2012, we placed skirts around the traps at the other terrestrial gradient plots (118, 218, 318, and 427).  On 5/30/2011 there was a significant hailstorm that created a lot of debris.  To asses the impact of this hailstorm, material from this hailstorm was collected from the baskets, but any non-hailstorm material was left in the litter trap (we could discern hailstorm litter because the leaves and twigs were fresh and/or green).  Those interested in looking at totals for that quarter should some both the "hailstorm" weights and the weights from material collected at the end of the same quarter.</para> </additionalInfo> <attributeList> <attribute id="att.1"> <attributeName>Year</attributeName> <attributeDefinition>Year collection was made</attributeDefinition> <storageType>integer</storageType> <measurementScale> <dateTime> <formatString>YYYY</formatString> <dateTimePrecision>1</dateTimePrecision> <dateTimeDomain> <bounds> <minimum exclusive="false">1994</minimum> <maximum exclusive="false">2014</maximum> </bounds> </dateTimeDomain> </dateTime> </measurementScale> <missingValueCode> <code>NaN</code> <codeExplanation>value not recorded or invalid</codeExplanation> </missingValueCode> </attribute> <attribute id="att.2"> <attributeName>Collection_Year</attributeName> <attributeDefinition>The "leaf year" that begins on April 1st and ends March 31st the following year.  This is how leaves should be summed. collected.</attributeDefinition> <storageType>integer</storageType> <measurementScale> <ordinal> <nonNumericDomain> <enumeratedDomain> <codeDefinition> <code>1</code> <definition>April -
